Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to reach his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he only take the elevator to the 7th floor on non-rainy days? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days.
Let me break this down step by step.
First, he lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor (which is the 1st floor) to go to work.
So that's a 9-floor descent each morning.
Then, in the evening, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and walks up the remaining 3 floors to his apartment on the 10th floor.
So, in the evening, he's taking the elevator up 7 floors and then walking up 3 floors.
Now, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way back up to the 10th floor.
So, on rainy days, he doesn't walk those 3 floors.
That makes sense because walking in the rain would be unpleasant, so he takes the elevator instead.
But why does he only go to the 7th floor on non-rainy days? Hmm.
Maybe it's about the time he takes or the effort involved.
If he takes the elevator all the way up to the 10th floor every time, that might take longer or be more effort, especially if he's in a hurry in the morning.
But wait, he takes the elevator down every morning, so maybe he's used to the elevator's timing.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator has certain rules or limitations.
Perhaps the elevator only goes up to the 7th floor during certain times or on certain days.
But that doesn't quite fit because he takes it to the ground floor every morning, which is much lower.
Wait, another angle: maybe the man is saving the elevator trips.
If he takes the elevator to the 7th floor in the evening, he can walk up the remaining 3 floors.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way, so he's using the elevator more on rainy days.
Maybe he's trying to conserve elevator usage or save time by not using the elevator on non-rainy days beyond the 7th floor.
Or perhaps it's about the effort of walking.
If he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor, he can walk up 3 floors, which might be quicker than waiting for the elevator again.
But on rainy days, he prefers the convenience of the elevator all the way, so he takes it to the 10th floor.
Wait, but the question is asking why he only takes it to the 7th floor on non-rainy days.
So it's about the difference between rainy and non-rainy days.
On rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way, so maybe on non-rainy days, he doesn't need the elevator as much, hence taking it only to the 7th floor and walking up.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator is faster or more efficient when going up, but that doesn't quite make sense.
Or perhaps the elevator has a limited capacity, and he doesn't want to wait on it during busy times.
Wait, another thought: maybe the man is trying to save time or avoid waiting for the elevator.

If he takes the elevator to the 7th floor, he can walk up the 3 floors quickly, whereas if he took the elevator all the way, he'd have to wait longer for it to come back up, especially if it's busy during the evening rush.
But why wouldn't he take the elevator all the way on non-rainy days then? Maybe it's about the effort of walking 3 floors versus waiting for the elevator.
If the elevator is faster, he might prefer to take it all the way, but in this case, he doesn't.
So perhaps the walking is quicker or more convenient.
Wait, but the problem says that on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way.
So on non-rainy days, he takes it only to the 7th floor.
That implies that on non-rainy days, he doesn't need the elevator beyond the 7th floor.
So maybe it's because when it's not raining, he can walk up the stairs more efficiently, while on rainy days, he prefers the convenience of the elevator.
Alternatively, maybe the man is trying to be efficient with elevator usage.
If he takes the elevator all the way every time, he'd be using it more, which could be inconvenient or time-consuming, especially if the elevator is slow or has limited capacity.
Wait, perhaps it's about the number of trips.
If he takes the elevator down every morning and then up in the evening, he's already using it twice a day.
On non-rainy days, he only needs to go up to the 7th floor, so he doesn't need to use the elevator again.
On rainy days, he needs to go all the way up, so he uses it again.
Hmm, that makes some sense.
So in the evening, if it's not raining, he can just walk up the 3 floors after taking the elevator to the 7th.
But on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way because he doesn't want to walk in the rain.
So the key point is that on non-rainy days, he can manage with taking the elevator only to the 7th floor and walking up, while on rainy days, he prefers the elevator all the way.
I think that's the reasoning.

So the answer is that on non-rainy days, he can walk up the stairs after the elevator takes him to the 7th floor, whereas on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way because he doesn't want to walk in the rain.

</think>

He takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days because after that, he can walk up the remaining 3 floors.
On rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to avoid walking in the rain.
